Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Energy Harvesting Wireless Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to establish fundamental performance limits and the ensuing design principles for wireless communication networks composed of devices that operate with energy harvested from the environment. These energy harvesting systems are envisioned to enable energy self-sufficient, energy self-sustaining, perpetually operating wireless networks, and untethered mobility. As such, they will enable new societal, medical, environmental, monitoring/surveillance and safety applications which are otherwise difficult or impossible with conventional battery-powered operation. These applications range from enabling perpetual remote environmental monitoring and surveillance, structural monitoring to on and in-body networking for health monitoring, medical diagnosis and treatment.

The project identifies the randomness, intermittency, and causality of energy availability, as well as the uncertainty about the energy states of the transmitters at the receivers, as new ingredients to be incorporated in determining the fundamental performance limits of energy harvesting wireless communication systems, and seeks to determine the information theoretic capacity of an energy harvesting link and the accompanying optimum coding and transmission scheme by incorporating energy harvesting constraints into the information theoretic capacity formulation. The project also seeks to identify the information capacity of multi-user, multi-hop, cooperative energy harvesting networks, as well as incorporating practical issues such as imperfections in storage and retrieval of energy to/from battery, leakage of energy over time, etc., into rigorous information theoretic capacity formulations. Furthermore, the project will make connections to estimation, privacy and security by investigating state amplification, state masking and secure data transmission problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project considered information capacity of channels where transmitting nodes harvest energy from nature into their rechargeable batteries to operate in an energy self-sufficient, energy self-sustaining manner. Such communication scenarios will be realized in future green wireless communication systems.

The major technical outcomes of this project include constructive algorithms for transmission of information in energy harvesting channels, as well as converse bounds. Taking the intermittency of energy availability as a design constraint on codebook construction, this project established communication rates achievable in battery-less, finite battery, and infinite battery scenarios, in the latter two considering the finite block-length performance. In particular, the project considered the transmission energy to be harvested from a stochastic energy arrival process, and examined the challenging case of finite energy storage where the corresponding overall channel model becomes one that deviates from the usual memoryless models of channels with state. The project provided an approach that transforms the model to that of a timing channel in a simple noiseless model with finite storage, and identified relevant capacity bounds. The project also provided introductory models and analysis for energy harvesting channels where the state of the channel (stemming from harvested intermittent energy) is intended to be kept private from the receiver.  Lastly, the project analyzed the finite block length performance of energy harvesting channels.

Educational outcomes of this research include incorporation of the produced research results into graduate curriculum, in particular in the form of a group of lectures as part of the newly developed graduate level course Emerging Topics in Networked Systems. Educational outreach activities included a number of tutorial lectures the PIs jointly offered at international conferences and workshops, as well as invited lecture at institutions and summer schools.

Human development and training outcomes of this research include training of PhD students at Penn State and at UMD on energy harvesting communications and gave them opportunities to conduct research on information theory and in the contemporary topic of green wireless communications. These PhD students have had the opportunity to collaborate closely with their peers as well as professors at different institutions, giving them richer learning experiences, and opportunities to participate in joint collaborative research.
